data.title: linux package names
data.body:
the linux package file names are:

vscode-i386.deb
vscode-i386.rpm

the pattern we have for the linux zips is this:
vscode-linux-ia32-insider.zip
vscode-linux-x64-insider.zip

I would expect then the packages to have names like this:
vscode-linux-deb-ia32-insider.deb
vscode-linux-rpm-ia32-insider.rpm

data.title: Ignore node_modules/vscode/typings/node.d.ts and use one of my own
data.body:
- VSCode Version: 0.11.8
- OS Version: Window 7

I'm developing an extension, and because the node.d.ts from vscode is not complete. I'm getting the following errors when running `node ./node_modules/vscode/bin/compile`

``` bash
src/lib/RemoteFile.ts(103,7): error TS2346: Supplied parameters do not match any signature of call target.
src/lib/Session.ts(75,58): error TS2339: Property 'indexOf' does not exist on type 'Buffer'.
```

The code in these lines are the following;

``` javascript
fs.writeSync(this.fd, buffer, offset, length);
```

and

``` javascript
buffer.indexOf(line);
```

which are valid, but as the node.d.ts is not complete, they are being considered invalid.

How can I ignore `node_modules/vscode/typings/node.d.ts` and use one of my own?

data.title: cannot move focus between buttons on message bar with keyboard
data.body:
Related to #3769 

I was able to get focus to the message bar on Windows (didn't try OSX yet) but i can't move between the buttons. Tab moves me off the message bar, left and right arrow don't do anything.

![image](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/1487073/13865009/e91e06b0-ec63-11e5-8105-d3ca9b7f419d.png)

data.title: Inconsistent behavior when viewing extension README/License
data.body:
- VSCode Version: 0.10.12-alpha
- OS Version: Windows 10

Steps to Reproduce:
1. Change default browser to IE or Chrome
2. In VS Code: F1 -> extension 
3. Click Readme or License

Actual:
When Edge is the default browser it stays minimized or in the background after clicking readme or license. If IE or Chrome is the default, it will pull the browser window over VS Code.

Expected:
Consistent behavior between browsers.

data.title: [Ruby] Unable to debug .rb file and getting debugger terminal error.
data.body:
- VSCode Version: 0.10.12-alpha
- OS Version: Windows10
  -Ruby Version: rubyinstaller-2.2.4-x64 (install location : http://rubyinstaller.org/downloads/)

Steps to Reproduce:
1. Launch app and open a folder which contains .rb file.
2. Install all the ruby extensions and restart app.
3. Add some break point in .rb file.
4. Debug .rb file  with option "Debug local file"

Actual: Getting Error like : Debugger terminal error: Process failed: spawn rdebug-ide.bat ENOENT 
![image](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/17735796/13863301/19ee6478-ec56-11e5-92b6-140a0812fbc7.png)

data.title: Copy Word in Cursor extension no longer working in 0.10.11
[Extension] Getting message like : can't lint "c:\.<xyz.rb" file , after installing ruby-linter extension.
data.body:
- VSCode Version:
- OS Version:

Steps to Reproduce:
1. Launch app and open a folder which contains .rb file.
2. Install Ruby and Ruby-linter extensions and verify .rb file for lint message.

Actual: 
1. Getting message like: "Cannot lint c:\src\Ruby\main.rb. The executable was not found. Use the 'ruby.executablePath' setting to configure the location of the executable"
![image](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/17735796/13863115/d3d6bbb2-ec54-11e5-8195-856efb07174c.png)
1. There is no entry in the default setting file for Ruby's extensions.

Note : I could see for other extensions (Like GO, PHP, ESLint etc.) there are some default configuration available in default setting file but for Ruby there is no entry. 
Expected: After installing the extension it should configure the default setting and linter should work properly.

data.title: [Extension][Ruby][Ruby-Linter] Ruby extensions are not displaying in the recommend extension list when opening ruby file or folder.
data.body:
- VSCode Version:0.10.12-alpha
- OS Version: Windows10

Steps to Reproduce:
1. Launch app and open any folder which contains a ruby project or .rb file. 
2. Click on extension info icon from task bar and select option for " Show extension recommendations" to get list of the extensions to be installed for current workspace project.

Actual: Ruby extension is not displaying in the show recommendations extension list.
![image](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/17735796/13862588/8f86fdbc-ec51-11e5-9f90-b61ad276f88f.png)

Expected: when user is opening a .rb file then it should display ruby extensions (ruby and ruby-lint) in the recommendations list.

data.title: Make color and shape of error markers configurable

_From @Franziskus1988 on March 3, 2016 14:6_

Sometimes it's difficult to find/see the green marked linting errors. Especially when a file contains a lot of comments (normally green).

Would it be possible to make the color and maybe the line thickness configurable?  

_Copied from original issue: Microsoft/vscode-tslint#31_

data.body: We have a dependency on the node-debugger from our extension, and it recently changed name. What's the correct way to declare an extension dependency on: andreweinand.node-debug or ms-vscode.node-debug?

data.title: High-contrast theme should be default when OS is in High-Contrast Mode

milestone.title: Backlog
milestone.description: Work not yet planned for a specific release.

data.body:
If a user's OS is in high-contrast mode, then it's important we can default him/her to the high-contrast theme.  Depending on visual acuity, switching to it could be difficult if she/he is not already in it.

For example, Chromium detects if Windows is in high-contrast mode (maybe we can learn from their way of doing it).  Perhaps, this is partly something we need Electron to adopt.

data.title: "Copy" as in Copy/Paste works intermittently from editor screen

milestone.title: Backlog
milestone.description: Work not yet planned for a specific release.

data.body:
- VSCode Version: Monaco bits used by extensions in Azure Portal at https://portal.azure.com
- OS Version: Windows 10

Originally reported by customers of Azure Automation extension of Azure Portal here: https://feedback.azure.com/forums/246290/suggestions/12269811

Steps to Reproduce (as stated by customers):
(User 1)
When trying to copy paste data, the copy works intermittently at best. I have not been able to reliably replicate a scenario where this works. I can literally select some text, copy it, paste it to notepad (or something else), then go back to copy something else and it fails to copy still retaining what I last had in the clipboard.

(User 2)
It happens for me in PowerShell editor with lots of code and many terms per line.  Also, I typically use Chrome.  It is intermittent.

data.body:

- OS Version: Windows 10

Steps to Reproduce:
1. Install Predawn theme
2. Change theme to Predawn Markdown

Actual: All text is red for any language type

Expected: Not entirely sure, but I would expect there to be some color differences. There is no documentation I could find on what to expect with this theme.

data.title: Markdown internal links within the page in preview mode are dead
data.body: - VSCode Version: 0.10.11 - OS Version:Win 10 Steps to Reproduce: 1. Link in markdown within the same page: `[Internal link](#TestLink)` 2. Header later in the same document: `####Test Link Heading ` I've tried option 2 with id instead of name, but no difference. The item looks like a link, and it changes my cursor to the little hand to click on the link, but the link is dead when I click on it. I've looked up how to properly use `marked` as described in the main vscode pages, but this isn't working... Is this me doing it wrong or is it something that needs to be fixed?

data.title: Debug: If debugging steps, stops, or restarts after a stopping event but before obtaining locals have finished, Loading graphic in the locals cannot be dismissed.
data.body:
- VSCode Version: 0.10.11
- OS Version: Win10

![image](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/6598594/13854579/66b230b4-ec29-11e5-9c06-cdb889913a5a.png)

Steps to Reproduce: I was able to reproduce this using the C# debugger from the [C# Extension](https://marketplace.visualstudio.com/items?itemName=ms-vscode.csharp), but I believe it is a UI issue and should repro with any debugadapter.
1. Run code that will hit a breakpoint
2. After the UI begins to stop, but before locals are populated, stop debugging (or restart debugging or step).

Expected: debugging stops, debugging UI is cleared of debug mode information

Actual: Locals loading graphic continues to be displayed. Locals are broken for subsequent debug session and code must be restarted to fix this.

data.title: Switching to inline diff view gives bad scrollbar position
data.body:
Use the following settings. It is important to use a larger font size such that the line numbers overall width must be large:

```
, "editor.fontFamily": "Hack"
, "editor.renderWhitespace": true
, "editor.fontSize": 16
, "editor.lineHeight": 22
```

Open diff side-by-side. Switch to inline. Observe, the scrollbar is not possitioned OK:

![diff-inline](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/5047891/13852841/4edf0e68-ec64-11e5-91d9-33180edd7291.gif)

data.title: Creating multiple cursors by using Cmd-Option-Down arrow goes to the next visual line, not the next logical line

milestone.title: Backlog
milestone.description: Work not yet planned for a specific release.

data.body:
- VSCode Version: 0.10.11
- OS Version: OS X 10.10.5

Steps to Reproduce:
1. write a long line of text that wraps in the editor
2. place the cursor on the first line and press Cmd-Option-Down (on OS X).

This creates a second cursor on the next visual line, which means it is somewhere on the same logical line depending on how the text is wrapped. When creating multiple cursors on adjacent lines, often it is to perform the same edit on multiple (logical) lines that are aligned with each other. The current behavior having the second cursor appear instead at some situation-specific place on the same logical line throws a wrench in this workflow. I can't think of a good situation where it makes sense (though I do realize it is consistent with pressing the down arrow without cmd-option)

Definitions: a logical line is a line in the file on disk. A visual line is a line in the editor. A logical line may span multiple visual lines when there is wrapping.

data.title: Wrong file icon when associating VS Code as default editor for an unknown file type

milestone.title: Backlog
milestone.description: Work not yet planned for a specific release.

data.body:
- VSCode Version: 0.10.11
- OS Version: Windows 10

Steps to Reproduce:
1. right click on an unknown file type, like `.vscodeignore` or `.eslintrc`
2. choose _Open with..._
3. Select VS Code and check _always use this app to open files of this type_

The file gets the app icon of VS Code, not the document icon:

![image](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/10532611/13850241/62eb28a2-ec59-11e5-8870-e4638eaf5b91.png)
